verses.text: For the kingdom of heaven is like a landowner who went out early in the morning to hire workers for his vineyard.
verses.comment: Jesus uses the imagery of a vineyard, echoing Isaiah 5:1-7, to describe God's kingdom. The landowner represents God, who initiates salvation and calls laborers at His own initiative.

verses.text: He agreed with the workers on a denarius a day and sent them into his vineyard.
verses.comment: A denarius was the usual daily wage for a laborer in that time, highlighting the fairness of the agreement between the landowner and the workers: salvation offered at God's initiative, not man's.

verses.text: Going out about the third hour, he saw others standing idle in the marketplace.
verses.comment: 'The third hour' in Jewish timing is around 9 a.m. The repeated calling throughout the day signifies God’s continual invitation to all people.

verses.text: He said to them, 'You also go into the vineyard, and whatever is right I will give you.' So they went.
verses.comment: The master’s generosity extends to those later called; the reward is promised based on his sense of justice.

verses.text: Again he went out about the sixth and the ninth hour, and did the same.
verses.comment: The sixth hour (noon) and the ninth hour (3 p.m.) further emphasize God’s relentless pursuit of workers. God does not tire of inviting people to His service throughout the ages.

verses.text: And about the eleventh hour he went out and found others standing, and he said to them, 'Why do you stand here idle all day?'
verses.comment: The eleventh hour (5 p.m.) signifies the last opportunity—a symbol that God offers grace up to the very end.

verses.text: 'They said to him, 'Because no one has hired us.' He said to them, 'You also go into the vineyard.'
verses.comment: There is a universal invitation to labor for the Lord; no one is excluded or denied entry even if they come late.

verses.text: When evening came, the owner of the vineyard said to his foreman, 'Call the workers and pay them their wages, beginning with the last up to the first.'
verses.comment: God's justice is timely and orderly, fulfilling the law to pay wages and turning human expectations upside down (cf. Matt. 19:30).

verses.text: And when those hired about the eleventh hour came, each of them received a denarius.
verses.comment: Those last to join get the same reward—emphasizing God's grace rather than strict legalism. This challenges any sense of presumption based on seniority.

verses.text: Now when those hired first came, they thought they would receive more, but each of them also received a denarius.
verses.comment: Human expectations are contrasted with God’s generosity. The spirit of humility is called for, rather than entitlement.

verses.text: And on receiving it, they grumbled against the landowner,
verses.comment: Complaining against God’s mercy echoes the grumbling of Israel in the wilderness, warning against envy in the spiritual life.

verses.text: 'These last worked only one hour, and you have made them equal to us who have borne the burden of the day and the scorching heat.'
verses.comment: The complaint highlights the tendency to compare and begrudge others God's generosity, similar to the elder brother’s attitude in the parable of the prodigal son.

verses.text: But he answered one of them, 'Friend, I am not doing you wrong. Did you not agree with me for a denarius?'
verses.comment: The landowner (God) is just in fulfilling his covenant. Salvation is gift, not debt.

verses.text: Take what belongs to you and go. I choose to give to this last as I give to you.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty in dispensing grace is absolute. He gives according to His will and love, not our limited ideas of fairness.

verses.text: 'Am I not allowed to do what I wish with what belongs to me? Or do you begrudge my generosity?'
verses.comment: The landowner questions the workers, exposing envy. There’s a reminder to appreciate divine generosity—teaching humility, especially regarding God’s grace dispensed through the means He chooses.

verses.text: So the last will be first, and the first last.
verses.comment: A summary of the parable’s lesson: God exalts the humble and humbles the exalted. This reversal is often seen in the Kingdom.

verses.text: As Jesus was going up to Jerusalem, He took the twelve aside privately and said to them on the way,
verses.comment: The journey to Jerusalem marks a turning point where Jesus reveals His redemptive mission to the Apostles.

verses.text: 'See, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be handed over to the chief priests and scribes, and they will condemn Him to death,
verses.comment: 'Son of Man' recalls the messianic prophecy of Daniel 7:13. Jesus predicts His passion, deliberate and fulfilling prophecy.

verses.text: and deliver Him over to the Gentiles to be mocked and flogged and crucified, and on the third day He will rise.'
verses.comment: A detailed prophecy of Christ's suffering and resurrection: mockery, scourging, and the crucifixion are mentioned. His resurrection on the third day is a clear divine claim fulfilling Old Testament prophecies (Isaiah 53, Psalm 16).

verses.text: Then the mother of the sons of Zebedee came to Him with her sons, kneeling before Him and asking something from Him.
verses.comment: The mother’s reverent posture (kneeling) before Jesus implicitly recognizes His authority and divinity.

verses.text: And He said to her, 'What do you want?' She said to Him, 'Say that these two sons of mine may sit, one at your right hand and one at your left, in your kingdom.'
verses.comment: Sitting at Christ's right and left implies positions of highest honor in His Kingdom, recalling Psalm 110:1 and the promise of thrones for the apostles.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup that I am about to drink?' They said to Him, 'We are able.'
verses.comment: 'The cup' symbolizes suffering and destiny (compare Isa. 51:22, Matt. 26:39). Jesus points to participation in His passion, foreshadowing Christian suffering for the sake of Christ.

verses.text: He said to them, 'You will indeed drink my cup, but to sit at my right hand and at my left is not mine to grant, but it is for those for whom it has been prepared by my Father.'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the apostles will share in His sufferings (Rom. 8:17), but heavenly offices are appointed by the Father’s sovereign decree. Notice the reference to divine authority and order.

verses.text: When the ten heard this, they were indignant with the two brothers.
verses.comment: The reaction exposes natural rivalry and ambition among the disciples, which Jesus seeks to transform.

verses.text: But Jesus called them to Him and said, 'You know that the rulers of the nations lord it over them, and their great ones exercise authority over them.'
verses.comment: Jesus contrasts worldly authority with the kind of servant leadership He requires in His Church.

verses.text: Yet it shall not be so among you. Instead, whoever would be great among you must be your servant,
verses.comment: True greatness in Christ’s Kingdom is found in humility and service, reflecting Jesus’ own example at the Last Supper (John 13:14-15).

verses.text: and whoever would be first among you must be your slave—
verses.comment: Jesus deepens the call: Christian leaders are to be humble, serving not only as servants but even as slaves, emptying themselves for others as Christ did.

verses.text: even as the Son of Man came not to be served but to serve, and to give His life as a ransom for many.'
verses.comment: 'Ransom for many' echoes Isaiah 53 and reveals Christ’s mission of sacrificial atonement. Here, Jesus alludes to His divinity—the ability to lay down His life for many.

verses.text: As they went out from Jericho, a great crowd followed Him.
verses.comment: Jericho is close to Jerusalem, marking the final approach before Jesus’ passion.

verses.text: And behold, two blind men sitting by the roadside, hearing that Jesus was passing by, cried out, 'Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!'
verses.comment: 'Son of David' asserts Jesus’ messianic identity (Isa. 35:5), and 'mercy' foreshadows the Church’s continuing prayer to Christ.

verses.text: And the crowd rebuked them, telling them to be silent. But they cried out even more, 'Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!'
verses.comment: The persistence of the blind men in calling Jesus 'Lord' and 'Son of David' is an act of faith, encouraging perseverance in prayer for mercy, a tradition carried on in worship.

verses.text: And Jesus stopped and called them, and said, 'What do you want Me to do for you?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ openness to their request demonstrates His compassion and willingness to respond directly to those who approach Him with faith.

verses.text: They said to Him, 'Lord, let our eyes be opened.'
verses.comment: Their plea mirrors prophecies of the Messiah opening the eyes of the blind (Isaiah 29:18), further affirming Jesus’ identity.

verses.text: And Jesus had compassion on them and touched their eyes. Immediately they regained their sight and followed Him.
verses.comment: The miracle demonstrates both Jesus’ compassion and divine power. The response of the formerly blind men is to follow Jesus, symbolizing the journey from spiritual blindness to discipleship.
